title: How can we avoid criticizing another person? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question first of all makes an assumption: Why is criticism of another person bad? In fact, the only way we ever grow is when someone gives us criticism. How can we possibly know if something that we're doing isn't good unless someone or something else tells us? Criticism is a metric. It's an exposure to a new idea and to a new measurement to our action. So, the question is, "How do we criticize someone well?" Recently, I was having struggles with women I cared very much about. As a result, I felt uniquely lacking in my conviction. For once, I was vulnerable to what others suggested. Most of the time, I am one of those people who knows exactly what he believes, on any score. (Sometimes, that belief may not be based in the most evidence or empathy, and sometimes it is based on the unmitigated gall that my brain can solve problems that others have yet to despite working harder, but that's simply me). In that moment, I was feeling like a feather being blown about in a hurricane. I was so easy to sway. When we give criticism, we have to be careful about how we are impacting others. Human beings are social animals. We deeply concern ourselves with how we are viewed by others, how we are liked and disliked, how others feel about us and in general. So when you criticize someone, consider, "Am I asking them to do something a) Fairb) Rightc) Implementabled) Practical"? There's a million examples. Let's say that we have someone at our work who is perpetually late, under our management. Should we say, "Grab your shit, you're incompetent and you're fired?" Okay, sometimes that's actually warranted. But maybe what we should start with is: "Why are you late? What's the problem?" If a friend keeps getting angry and blowing up at us, we have to consider, "Am I asking them never to be angry at me, or am I simply asking them to do something better?" If I don't ask that question, I might say, "You're always angry. It's really unpleasant and you're being a jerk". Now, that might not be unfair, but it's a pretty massive implicit request we are issuing: "Never be angry, or at least swallow it forever". How about we ask, "Okay, next time you're angry, I'd like you to wait a few moments then write down the complaint, and then e-mail it to me later so that way I can hear it in a calmer way?" That's something that's fair, it's implementable, it's practical. It doesn't ask them to change everything, just to shift a little bit. We can justly be frustrated if they don't accommodate that request. Now, if your habit is that you criticize people unduly and too often, just remember your own flaws and how they might make other people feel. At first, this will be hard, but the more you do it, the easier it will become. So, in conclusion: Don't worry about giving criticism, be worried about giving criticism well.

As I write this answer, I'm clenching my teeth because I'm presently dealing with a difficult person at work!  To answer the question, it's very hard to avoid criticizing another person, especially if they're uncooperative, abrasive or have other undesirable traits or behaviors. What I've learn is they're usually not impacted by your opinion or critique. Therefore, as others have written, it's best to take a deep breath, and try to move past the negativity and focus on their positive attributes.  Explain your point-of-view, and how what they're doing is impacting your feelings, project, career, etc. Consider whether what the other person is doing is truly related to you.  For instance, are you impacted by your friend who regularly wears unkempt, grungy clothing? Probably not. However, if the person is a co-worker who interfaces with the public, and isn't suitably dressed, then it might be worthwhile to mention how the person's dress reflects poorly on others in the group, and potentially, the employer.  Remember, criticism can be constructive. If possible, frame your critique as a friendly, non-offensive recommendation.

The best way is to stop neglecting yourself by wasting the minutes of your life and the energy of your body on other people. Spend more time on improving your damn self instead of dedicating your life to people who would hate you for a horrible habit. There’s constructive criticism and destructive criticism. One is to be avoided at all costs and the other MUST be limited - you cannot engage in constructive criticism everyday. If you have to give feedback in the form of criticism: schedule a time, convene a meeting, let everybody know in advance what will be happening, don’t single out one person…etc Thanks for visiting America

Hi, Anass, Your clear intention to do so is a good start. So, be clear with yourself. The habit of criticizing others may have roots in your own feelings of insecurity. So, do some spiritual work and you will hopefully come to the realization that you are a totally worthy human being. A great book to help with this is Richard Rohr’s Immortal Diamond. It sounds like criticizing others is a habit. To break it, you need to do things to remind yourself. A twice-a-day journaling where you actually review your actions during the day for this purpose would probably work well …and it would make you a more mindful and aware person altogether. Good luck! Ray

The fact you recognize your own behavior is commendable. The reason why you criticise others is because you find or see fault in the way they “should” act. It’s not an abnormal state of being for somebody who is “supposed to be this or that”. Maybe your own parents were very strict on you, making it impossible for you to do anything they did not like. I found a lot of support in psychotherapy. If you want to stop seeing fault in everyone around you, tackle the faults in yourself.

Most often the person you are being critical of can represent aspects of yourself that you see in the other.It's that other person that we find difficult is the person who can teach us more of who we are.This is called projections. It's unconsciously seeing ourselves in another.Withdrawal of projections is making more consciousness in ourselves.When you find yourself being critical of another stop and ask yourself, can I be like this in some way?Best wishes.

Very likely, when you are more confident in yourself, you will not feel a need to criticize others. Until then, realize when you criticize others, you are only revealing lack within yourself. However much many people miss this, a lot don’t. Regardless, people don’t feel safe around those who criticize others as they wonder what they’re saying behind their back? So, every time you criticize another person you’re doing more harm to yourself than you are to them. That bit of information should be enough to help you stop!

It is a skill that requires practice. When a teacher is mentoring a pupil there is a wide disparity between them in their knowledge.  It would be easy for the teacher to criticize the student for their lack of knowledge. The teacher has to suppress their urge to do this because it is counterproductive.  The skill that the teacher has to practice is called patience.  Change your thoughts of criticizing to thoughts of teaching. Share your knowledge and don't belittle theirs.

When you get the urge to be critical, stop and think that they might not have had the opportunities that you have been blessed to have. Second, learn to have compassion and that means to have an intellectual understanding of their situation. This will help you move from an unhappy, critical person to an understanding, balanced, and joyful person.

You should learn to accept people as they are , sometimes all things are not as you want and criticizing means you are just letting negative and bad things over your mind , and spreading bad vibes so start loving people and yourself too ,that will add grace to your life !

This is often a characteristic of people with low self-esteem who lack confidence and were bullied or belittled in their lives. The best way to stop stop thinking critical thoughts in your mind about people and automatically believe negative things about them. Just try to get out of this habit and you'll stop criticizing them out loud.
By thinking deeper and understanding why the person has those things that you want to criticize. Perhaps realizing that there is a story behind each person you see can help.
would you like to be criticized? Pythagoras said criticizing others is putting their excreta in your mouth.Just look within ,are you perfect.We all are good only viewpoints are different.
Schedule a special period everyday just to criticize people. You’ll find the time.
